prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6 for A1A2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detecting two CO transitions for each X-ray luminous, dusty galaxy, each with two CO transitions in the bands B4/B6. The goals are to determine their molecular gas content and kinematics, the gas consumption time scale, thus their possible evolutionary stages towards naked quasars, and to constrain the dominant powering source in the FIR, AGN or starburst. The derived L'(CO)-L(FIR) correlation will also enable us to test that if X-ray luminous, starburst galaxies are more depleted in gas than normal starbursts of comparable FIR luminosities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A2 (z=1.6780) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A1. The A1 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z=0.7788 in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of both targets will be marginally detected. The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if the host of these dusty quasars are extended as in their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in 8-20kpc scale.
For the lines, the lower S/N of the two is still high: ~14 for A2 CO 6-5 at a line width of 400 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is 24%.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band4 for A1A2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detecting two CO transitions for each X-ray luminous, dusty galaxy, each with two CO transitions in the bands B4/B6. The goals are to determine their molecular gas content and kinematics, the gas consumption time scale, thus their possible evolutionary stages towards naked quasars, and to constrain the dominant powering source in the FIR, AGN or starburst. The derived L'(CO)-L(FIR) correlation will also enable us to test that if X-ray luminous, starburst galaxies are more depleted in gas than normal starbursts of comparable FIR luminosities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 2-1 transition for A1 (z=0.7788) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A2. The A2 CO 3-2 transition is then manually entered using the real z=1.6780 in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.30 mJy, the continuum of the 2 targets will not be detected. The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 4 (~3 mm).
For the lines, the lower S/N of the two is still high: ~7 for A2 CO 3-2 for a line width of 400 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is 26%.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band4 for A3A4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detecting two CO transitions for each X-ray luminous, dusty galaxy, each with two CO transitions in the bands B4/B6. The goals are to determine their molecular gas content and kinematics, the gas consumption time scale, thus their possible evolutionary stages towards naked quasars, and to constrain the dominant powering source in the FIR, AGN or starburst. The derived L'(CO)-L(FIR) correlation will also enable us to test that if X-ray luminous, starburst galaxies are more depleted in gas than normal starbursts of comparable FIR luminosities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 42' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 2-1 transition for A4 (z=0.8267) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A3. The A3 CO 3-2 transition is then manually entered using the real z=1.7560 in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.30 mJy, the continuum of the A3 will be marginally detected, and ignorable for A4. The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 4 (~3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.4" in B4 yields a linear scale of 3.0-3.5 kpc at z=0.8-1.7. For A3, we can test if the host of these dusty quasars are extended as in their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in 8-20kpc scale.
For the lines, the lower S/N of the two is still high: ~8 for A3 CO 3-2 for a line width of 400 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is 25%.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6 for A3A4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detecting two CO transitions for each X-ray luminous, dusty galaxy, each with two CO transitions in the bands B4/B6. The goals are to determine their molecular gas content and kinematics, the gas consumption time scale, thus their possible evolutionary stages towards naked quasars, and to constrain the dominant powering source in the FIR, AGN or starburst. The derived L'(CO)-L(FIR) correlation will also enable us to test that if X-ray luminous, starburst galaxies are more depleted in gas than normal starbursts of comparable FIR luminosities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 42' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A3 (z=1.7560) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A4. The A4 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z= 0.8267in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of the 2 targets will be detected for both A3 and A4 (>= 3 sigma). The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if the host of these dusty quasars are extended as in their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in 8-20kpc scale.
For the lines, the lower S/N of the two is still high: ~12 for A4 CO 4-3 for a line width of 400 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is 25%.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: AGNs in dusty galaxies are revealed by their powerful X-ray emission, along with bright IR dust emission. These exceptional X-ray and FIR luminous objects are very rare and only detected in large area (> 1 deg sq) surveys, e.g. one starburst quasar (z=1.826) in the COSMOS field and one obscured quasar (z=3.427) in the CFHTLS-deep fields. These objects are special candidates possibly in transition between ULIRGs and FIR faint, unobscured quasars. We searched for dusty X-ray objects at z~1-2 in the 11 deg sq XMM-LSS field, with public X-ray and FIR data. We found 4 sources, two at z~0.8 and two at z~1.7, with Lx(2-10 keV)=(1.4-4.4)*10^44 erg/s, L(FIR)=(0.11-1.7)*10^13 Lsun, and T(dust)= 22-38 K. We aim at detecting two CO transitions for each target in bands B4/B6. The goals are to determine their gas content and kinematics, the gas consumption time scale, thus the evolutionary stages towards naked quasars, and to study the correlation between the gas and dust components. The L'(CO)-L(FIR) relation will enable us to test if X-ray luminous starburst galaxies are more depleted in gas than normal starbursts of comparable L(FIR).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 1 Project Code: 2012.1.00569.S, ranked 20-40% and not awarded time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
